column3: IPA: [ˈzɑslɐu̯]; Polish: Zasław) is one of the oldest cities in Volhynia. Situated on the Horyn river (Ukrainian: Горинь) in western Ukraine
column4: the city dates back to the 11th century. Population: 16

column1: Izyaslav was first mentioned in 1390. It was a private town of Poland
column2: owned by the families of Zasławski and Sanguszko. It was part of Polish Volhynian Voivodeship. In 1583 it was granted Magdeburg city rights.

column1: After the Partitions of Poland Izyaslav was part of the Russian Empire - Volhynian Governorate.
At the beginning of World War II
column2: the town had an important Jewish population representing 28% of the total inhabitants. As soon as the Germans occupied the town
column3: Jews were kept imprisoned in a ghetto and later murdered in mass executions perpetrated by an Einsatzgruppen.
